revision.comment: /* Italy */ deleted ref as no mention of eating rabbits in Europe
revision.text:
{{For|meat eaten by cats|cat food}} [[File:Cats before slaughter 03.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Cats for sale as food in an East Asian market area. They will either be sold live for use in restaurants or slaughtered on site, dressed, and sold as meat.]] '''Cat meat''' is meat prepared from [[domestic cat]]s for human consumption. Some countries eat cat meat regularly, whereas others have only consumed cat meat in desperation during wartime or poverty.
==Africa== Prehistoric human feces have contained bones from the wild cat of Africa.<ref name="TaylorNegus1989">{{cite book|author1=David Taylor|author2=Daphne Negus|author3=Dave King |author4=Jane Burton |title=The Ultimate Cat Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rPdFgZzns30C&pg=PA9&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEIQjAH#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|year=1989|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-671-68649-9|pages=9–}}</ref>
In some cultures of [[Cameroon]], there is a special ceremony featuring cat-eating that is thought to bring good luck.<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2857891.stm|title= The cat eaters of Cameroon|publisher = BBC News | date=2003-03-17 | first=Francis | last=Ngwa-Niba}}</ref>
==Asia==
=== China === In [[Guangdong]] and [[Guangxi]] provinces in south-eastern [[China]], some—especially older—people consider cat flesh a good warming food during winter months. However, in northern China eating cat is considered unacceptable. <ref name=Xinhuanet/>
In Guangdong, cat meat is a main ingredient in the traditional dish "[[Dragon tiger phoenix |dragon, tiger, phoenix]]" (snake, cat, chicken), which is said to fortify the body.<ref name=Xinhuanet>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/indepth/2012-01/13/c_131358233.htm Some call it an indelicate trade, others, a delicacy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314075006/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/indepth/2012-01/13/c_131358233.htm |date=2017-03-14 }}, Xinhuanet.com, 13 Jan 2012 (from China Daily)</ref>
Organized cat-collectors supply the southern restaurants with animals that often originate in [[Anhui]] and [[Jiangsu]] provinces.<ref name=Xinhuanet/><ref>{{Cite news|url= http://beijingtoday.com.cn/2008/12/nanjing-sends-meat-meows-guangzhou/|title= Nanjing sends meat that meows to Guangzhou | publisher = Beijing Today | location=Beijing | first=Yu | last=Wang | date=2008-12-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/4061850/Cat-nappers-feed-Cantonese-taste-for-pet-delicacy.html|title= Cat-nappers feed Cantonese taste for pet delicacy|publisher = Telegraph | location=London | first=Malcolm | last=Moore | date=2009-01-01}}</ref> On 26 January 2010 China launched its first draft proposal to protect the country's animals from maltreatment including a measure to jail people, for periods up to 15 days, for eating cat or dog meat.<ref name="China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog (China Daily)">{{cite web| url =http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-01/26/content_9379689.htm | accessdate=2010-01-26 | publisher=Chinadaily |title = China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=107622&z=5|title = Trung Quốc sắp sửa cấm ăn thịt chó, mèo}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{vi}}</ref>
With the increase of cats as pets in [[China]], opposition towards the traditional use of cats for food has grown. In June 2006, approximately 40 activists stormed the Fangji Cat Meatball Restaurant in [[Shenzhen]], forcing it to shut down.<ref name="Fangji Cat Meatball Restaurant (Reuters)">{{Cite news |url=http://today.reuters.com/News/newsArticle.aspx?type=oddlyEnoughNews&storyID=2006-06-19T131415Z_01_PEK331544_RTRUKOC_0_US-CHINA-CATS.xml |accessdate=2006-10-22 |publisher=Reuters |title=Animal rights protest shuts restaurant |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060713014909/http://today.reuters.com/News/newsArticle.aspx?type=oddlyEnoughNews |archivedate=2006-07-13 |df= }}</ref> Expanded to more than 40 member societies, the [[Chinese Animal Protection Network]] in January 2006 began organizing well-publicized protests against dog and cat consumption, starting in [[Guangzhou]], following up in more than ten other cities "with very optimal response from public."<ref name="Guangzhou bans eating snakes--ban helps cats(Animal People)">{{cite web |url=http://www.animalpeoplenews.org/07/11/guangzhoubanseatingsnakes11_07.html |accessdate=2008-02-16 |publisher=Reuters via animalpeoplenews.org |title=Guangzhou bans eating snakes--ban helps cats |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304213111/http://www.animalpeoplenews.org/07/11/guangzhoubanseatingsnakes11_07.html |archivedate=2008-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
=== Japan === In Japan, cat meat was consumed until the end of [[Tokugawa period]] in the 19th century.<ref name="hanleycat66">{{Cite book|last = Hanley|first = Susan|title = Everyday Things in Premodern Japan|year = 1997|page = 66}}</ref> [[Ryukyuan people|Okinawans]] once ate a cat soup called ''Mayaa no Ushiru'' ([[:ja:マヤーのウシル|マヤーのウシル]]).
=== Korea === In [[Korea]], cat meat was historically brewed into a tonic as a folk remedy for [[neuralgia]] and [[arthritis]]. Modern consumption is more likely to be as cat soup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saynotodogmeat.net/2014/02/19/boiled-alive-cat-meat-soup-south-korea/ |title=Boiled Alive Cat Meat Soup, South Korea |work=SAY NO TO DOG MEAT.NET |accessdate=22 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123001003/http://saynotodogmeat.net/2014/02/19/boiled-alive-cat-meat-soup-south-korea/ |archivedate=23 November 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idausa.org/campaigns/dogs-cats/dogs-and-cats-of-south-korea/|title=Dog and Cat Meat Consumption – In Defense of Animals – In Defense of Animals|work=In Defense of Animals|accessdate=22 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123043818/http://www.idausa.org/campaigns/dogs-cats/dogs-and-cats-of-south-korea/|archivedate=23 November 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://our-compass.org/2012/04/09/ban-south-korean-dog-and-cat-meat-trade/|title=Ban South Korean dog and cat meat trade|work=Our Compass|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>http://www.examiner{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. com/article/south-korea-dog-cat-meat-industry-to-face-protests</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animalliberationfront.com/ALFront/Actions-Korea/KoreaDogMeatUpdate.htm|title=Important Update On South Korean Dog And Cat Meat Trade|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://koreandogs.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023065537/http://koreandogs.org/ |archivedate=2015-10-23 |df= }}</ref>
=== Vietnam === Cat meat is eaten in Vietnam, even though it is technically illegal.<ref name="meovb">Việt Báo [http://vietbao.vn/The-gioi-giai-tri/Thanh-pho-thit-meo/50760981/407/ Thịt mèo]</ref><ref name="tptm">[http://tuoitre.vn/Chinh-tri-Xa-hoi/Phong-su-Ky-su/99714/Thanh-pho-thit-meo.html Thành phố thịt mèo]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailymeal.com/9-countries-eat-cats-and-dogs-slideshow|title=9 Countries That Eat Cats and Dogs (Slideshow)|work=The Daily Meal|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailymeal.com/9-countries-eat-cats-and-dogs/11414|title=9 Countries That Eat Cats and Dogs|work=The Daily Meal|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vietnamcoracle.com/cat-meat/|title=Cat Meat|work=Vietnam Coracle|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedropoutdiaries.com/2012/11/the-truth-about-cats-dogs-in-vietnam/|title=The Truth About Cats & Dogs In Vietnam - The Dropout Diaries|work=The Dropout Diaries|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/travel/international/5337677/Where-cat-sits-happily-on-the-menu|title=Where cat sits happily on the menu|work=Stuff|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-News/2010/0722/Why-do-Vietnamese-keep-cats-on-a-leash-Hint-What-s-for-dinner|title=Why do Vietnamese keep cats on a leash? (Hint: What's for dinner?)|author=The Christian Science Monitor|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> It is generally seen on menus with the euphemism "[[wiktionary:tiểu hổ|tiểu hổ]]", literally "baby tiger" rather than the literal "[[wiktionary:thịt|thịt]] [[wiktionary:mèo|mèo]]". Cat galls have [[aphrodisiac]]al properties according to people in North Vietnam.<ref name="Hopkins2004">{{cite book|author=Jerry Hopkins|title=Extreme Cuisine: The Weird and Wonderful Foods That People Eat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ZPTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA25&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|date=15 May 2004|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|isbn=978-1-4629-0472-3|pages=25–}}</ref><ref name="Hopkins2014">{{cite book|author=Jerry Hopkins|title=Strange Foods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WXtzBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA8&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|date=23 December 2014|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|isbn=978-1-4629-1676-4|pages=8–}}</ref>
=== India === Cat meat is eaten in some parts of India, even though it is technically illegal.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} It is generally cooked with flavoured rice and is part of the main course during wedding feasts in the [[Narikurava]] community; cat soup is also served on the occasion of the birth of a male child.<ref name="huffindia">{{cite news|publisher=HuffingtonPost|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/11/01/for-biryani-in-chennai-cats-are-being-boiled-alive/?ncid=fcbklnkinhpmg00000001|title=For biryani in Chennai, cats are being boiled alive, sold for Rs 100 per kg|accessdate=November 3, 2016|date=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
==Europe==
===Switzerland=== In Switzerland the private consumption and slaughter of dog and cat meat is permitted though its commercial trade is prohibited by law. A 1993 petition to ban consumption failed with the government declaring the matter a "personal ethical choice."
===Denmark=== In June 2008, three students at the Danish School of Media and Journalism published pictures of a cat being slaughtered in ''Citat'', a magazine for journalism students. Their goal was to create a debate about [[animal welfare]]. The cat was shot by its owner, a [[farmer]], and it would have been [[animal euthanasia|put down]] in any case. The farmer [[animal slaughter|slaughtered]] the cat all within the limits of [[Law of Denmark|Danish law]]. This led to criticism from Danish animal welfare group Dyrenes Beskyttelse,<ref name="Journalistelever spiser kat">{{cite news |last=Walsh|first=Kevin|date=2008-06-05|title=Journalistelever spiser kat|trans_title=Journalism students eat cat |url=http://www.bt.dk/nyheder/journalistelever-spiser-kat|language=Danish |newspaper=[[B.T. (tabloid)|BT]]|publisher=[[Berlingske Media]]|accessdate=2013-10-28}}</ref><ref name="Journaliststuderende spiser kat på nettet">{{cite news | last = Andreassen| first = Andreas Marckmann| date = 2008-06-06 | title = Journaliststuderende spiser kat på nettet| trans_title = Journalism students eat cat online| url = http://www.journalisten.dk/journaliststuderende-spiser-kat-pa-nettet| language = Danish | newspaper = Journalisten.dk| publisher = Journalisten| accessdate = 2013-10-28}}</ref> and [[death threat]]s received by the students.<ref name="Århus-studerende spiste kat - nu trues de på livet">{{cite news |last=Helmer|first=Jesper|date=2008-06-07|title=Århus-studerende spiste kat - nu trues de på livet |trans_title=Students from Århus ate cat - are now threatened on their life |url=http://www.avisen.dk/aarhus-studerende-spiste-kat-nu-trues-de-paa-livet_11831.aspx|language=Danish |newspaper=Avisen.dk|publisher=Avisen.dk ApS|accessdate=2013-10-28}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In 18th-century Britain, there are a few records of cats being eaten as a form of entertainment.<ref name="The Cat Eaters">{{cite web |url=http://www.forteantimes.com/features/articles/260/the_cat_eaters.html |accessdate=2009-10-12 |title=The Cat Eaters |publisher=forteantimes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521072202/http://www.forteantimes.com/features/articles/260/the_cat_eaters.html |archivedate=2009-05-21 |df= }}</ref>
===Italy=== In February 2010, on a television cooking show, the [[Italy|Italian]] food writer Beppe Bigazzi mentioned that during the famine in [[World War II]] cat stew was a "succulent" and well known dish in his home area of [[Valdarno]], [[Tuscany]]. Later he claimed he had been joking, but added that cats used to be eaten in the area during famine periods, historically; he was widely criticised in the media for his comments and ultimately dropped from the television network.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/food_and_drink/article7029058.ece|title = Celebrity chef Beppe Bigazzi upsets viewers with his cat casserole|date = February 16, 2010 |publisher = The Times | location=London | first=Richard | last=Owen}}</ref>
Cats were sometimes eaten as a [[famine food]] during harsh winters, poor harvests, and wartime. Cat gained notoriety as "roof rabbit" in [[Central Europe]]'s hard times during and between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.messybeast.com/eat-cats.htm |title=Cats - Friend Or Food |publisher=Messybeast.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-14}}</ref>
Cat consumption was a stereotype attributed to Vincenzans in [[Vicenza]], Italy.<ref name="Albala2003">{{cite book|author=Ken Albala|title=Food in Early Modern Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4f-l3-KG0LcC&pg=PA66&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEIMTAE#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|year=2003|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31962-4|pages=66–}}</ref>
According to the "Butchers' Advocate, Dressed Poultry and the Food Merchant" in 1904, ''"Just before Christmas it is common for a group of young men in northern Italy to kill some cats, skin them and soak them in water for two or three days. They are cooked with great care on Christmas day and served up hot about 1.30 P. M., after mass. "Many people in Italy, 'on the quiet,' keep cats like the English do rabbits—to kill. A catskin there is worth ten pence, as the material for muffs for girls. "Extraordinary care has to be taken in procuring the animals, for the Italian Society for the Protection of Cats is vigilant, and offenses against the law are followed by imprisonment only. We have no fines in Italy.''<ref>{{cite book|title=Butchers' Advocate, Dressed Poultry and the Food Merchant|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E5tRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PP53&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEITzAJ#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|year=1904|pages=11–}}</ref>
According to "The Dietetic & Hygienic Gazette" in 1905, ''Italy cultivates the cat for home consumption as English people raise rabbits. It is to be done on the quiet, however, for in spite of the profit in the business and the demand for the delicacy, the law has to be looked out for, and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Cats is vigilant. Offenses against the law are visited with imprisonment. Cats are raised for the market none the less. Fattened on the finest of milk, a choice specimen will attain the weight of fifteen pounds.''<ref>{{cite book|title=The Dietetic & Hygienic Gazette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n3w3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA99&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEIJzAC#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|year=1905|publisher=Gazette Publishing Company|pages=99–100}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Dietetic and Hygienic Gazette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YfEgAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA99&dq=northern+italy+eat+cats&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik2qSL88LPAhXGGh4KHYk9ApkQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=northern%20italy%20eat%20cats&f=false|year=1905|publisher=Gazette Publishing Company|pages=99–100}}</ref>
===France and Spain=== There are recounts of cat being consumed in France's Gallia Norbon region and Spain in the 17th century.<ref name="Albala2003"/>
==Oceania== ===Australia=== [[Indigenous Australians]] in the area of [[Alice Springs, Northern Territory#Wild Cat Stew Challenge|Alice Springs]] roast feral cats on an open fire. They have also developed recipes for cat stew. Some other inhabitants of the area have also taken up this custom, justified on the grounds that felines are "a serious threat to Australia's native [[fauna]]". Scientists warned that eating wild cats could expose humans to harmful [[bacteria]] and [[toxins]].<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6974687.stm|publisher= BBC News|title= Australians cook up wild cat stew | date=2007-09-02 | first=Phil | last=Mercer}}</ref>
==The Americas== ===Peru=== Cat is not a regular menu item in [[Peru]], but is used in such dishes as [[fricassee]] and stews most abundant in two specific sites in the country: the southern town of [[Chincha Alta]] ([[Ica Region]], [[Afro-Peruvian]] mostly) and the north-central [[Andean]] town of [[Huari, Peru|Huari]] ([[Ancash Region]]). Primarily used by [[Afro-Peruvian]]s. Cat cooking techniques are demonstrated every September during the festival of [[Ephigenia|Saint Efigenia]] in a town of La Quebrada.<ref name="FEATURE - 'Cat-eaters' take note - feline feast at Peru festival">{{cite web| url = http://www.planetark.com/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/12575/newsDate/28-Sep-2001/story.htm| accessdate=2008-02-16 | title='Cat-eaters' take note - feline feast at Peru festival|publisher = planetark.com}}</ref>
In October 2013, a judge banned the annual El Festival Gastronomico del Gato (the Gastronomic Festival of the Cat), which was held every September in La Quebrada to commemorate the arrival of settlers who were forced to eat cats to survive, citing it as cruel to the 100+ cats specifically bred for the event, which involves being kept in cages for a year prior the Festival. The judge also cited concerns over the safety of the meat, which drew criticism from residents who contend that cat meat is far richer than rabbit or duck, and that it has been long consumed globally without any deleterious effects.<ref>Golgowksi, Nina (October 15, 2013). [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/judge-bans-peruvian-town-annual-cat-eating-festival-article-1.1486233 "Judge bans Peruvian town's annual cat-eating festival"]. ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' (New York).</ref>
That same month, magistrate Maria Luyo banned the festival of Curruñao in the small town of San Luis. Locals say that the festival, which sees cats being drowned, skinned and tied to fireworks and blown up, dates back to the practice of eating cat on the part of African slaves who worked on sugar-cane plantations in colonial times, and is part of the religious celebrations of [[Santa Efigenia]], an African-Peruvian folk saint. Luyo stated in her ruling that the festival "fomented violence based on cruel acts against animals which caused grave social damage and damaged public health", and that minors could be "psychologically damaged" by watching the events.<ref>Collyns, Dan (October 18, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/peru-judge-suspends-cat-race-feast "Claws out as Peruvian judge suspends annual cat race and feast"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref> ===Argentina=== In a 1996, report some citizens in a [[shanty town]] in [[Rosario, Santa Fe]], [[Argentina]], stated that, during an economic crisis, they had to feed the neighborhood children with cat's meat, and commenting, "It's not denigrating to eat cat, it keeps a child's stomach full". The validity of this report has been questioned, however.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiempo.infonews.com/nota/89339/nunca-se-comieron-los-gatos-en-rosario |title=Nunca se comieron gatos en Rosario |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106103721/http://tiempo.infonews.com/nota/89339/nunca-se-comieron-los-gatos-en-rosario |archivedate=2015-01-06 |df= }}</ref>
==Jewish and Islamic tradition== The [[Judaism|Jewish]] laws of [[kashrut]] and [[Islam]]ic [[Islamic dietary laws|dietary laws]] both [[taboo food and drink|forbid]] the consumption of cat meat.<ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|21|4752}}</ref> Kashrut disallows the consumption of any terrestrial predators. To be considered kosher in the case of mammals, it must not be a predator and it must both chew cud and have [[cloven hooves]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Rabbi Louis Jacobs |url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/kosher-animals/ |title=Kosher Animals |publisher=My Jewish Learning |date=2014-01-31 |accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewfaq.org/kashrut.htm |title=Judaism 101: Kashrut: Jewish Dietary Laws |publisher=Jewfaq.org |date= |accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref>
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Dog meat]] * [[Horse meat]] * [[List of meat animals]] * [[Taboo food and drink]] {{div col end}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox organization | name = Crumbs and Whiskers | native_name = | image =Crumbs and Whiskers logo.png | image_size = 250px | alt = Crumbs logo | caption = Crumbs and Whiskers logo | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | formation = {{start date|2015|06|20}} | founder = Kanchan Singh | type = [[Cat café]] | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = | location = {{•}}3211 O St NW, {{nowrap|[[Washington, D.C.]]}} 20007
{{•}}7924 Melrose Ave, {{nowrap|[[Los Angeles, CA]]}} 90048 | coords = | region = [[Washington metropolitan area]]
[[Los Angeles metropolitan area]] | services = {{flatlist|Cat interaction{{•}}Cat adoption}} | products = {{flatlist|[[Coffee]] {{•}}[[Tea]] {{•}}[[Cookies]]}} | methods = | fields = | language = | owner = Kanchan Singh {{small|(Co-owner)}}
Chetan Singh {{small|(Co-owner)}}{{cite web|authors=Sarah Le|title=Los Angeles’ First Cat Cafe Is Cat-Lover Heaven|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2164439-los-angeles-first-cat-cafe-is-cat-lover-heaven/|publisher=Epoch Times|accessdate=January 1, 2017|date=September 30, 2016}} | key_people = | affiliations = {{•}}[[The Humane Society of the United States|The Humane Society]]
{{•}}[[Karma Rescue]] | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = [http://www.crumbsandwhiskers.com {{nowrap|www.crumbsandwhiskers.com}}] | remarks = Financed via [[Kickstarter]]: [https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/2006072669/crumbs-and-whiskers-washington-dcs-cat-cafe Link] | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Crumbs and Whiskers''' is a [[small business]] which operates [[cat café]]s, or [[coffeehouse]]s that feature [[cats]] as an attraction, in {{nowrap|[[Washington, D.C.]]}} and [[Los Angeles]], California. Crumbs and Whiskers opened its first cat café in Washington on June 20, 2015; this was the first cat café to open in the [[Washington metropolitan area]].{{refn|{{cite web|author1=Perry Stein|title=Meet the woman who left her consulting job to open D.C.’s first cat cafe|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/02/06/meet-the-woman-who-left-her-consulting-job-to-open-d-c-s-first-cat-cafe/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=February 6, 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Perry Stein|title=Not-yet-open D.C. cat cafe raises serious money in 1 day|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/03/09/not-yet-open-d-c-cat-cafe-raises-serious-money-in-1-day/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=March 9, 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Maura Judkis|title=So, how would a cafe crawling with adorable kittens pass a D.C. health inspection?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/going-out-guide/wp/2014/11/20/so-how-would-a-cafe-crawling-with-adorable-kittens-pass-a-d-c-health-inspection/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=November 20, 2014}}{{cite web|author1=Courtney Pomeroy|title=D.C.’s Cat Cafe, Crumbs and Whiskers, Makes Strides Toward Opening This Year|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2015/03/23/d-c-s-cat-cafe-crumbs-and-whiskers-makes-strides-toward-opening-this-year/|publisher=CBS|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=March 23, 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Rachel Nania|title=Founder shares plans for D.C.’s first cat café, Crumbs and Whiskers|url=http://wtop.com/food/2015/02/plans-continue-d-c-s-first-cat-cafe/|website=WTOP|publisher=Washington's Top News|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=February 18, 2015}}|group="sources"|name="Notability"}} The Washington D.C. café is partnered with the local chapter of the [[The Humane Society of the United States|Humane Society]] in order to provide a boarding space for around 15–25 cats at a time.{{cite web|author1=Caroline Tucker|title=Cat cafe pounces forward in D.C.|url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2015/03/cat-cafe-pounces-forward-in-d-c--112694.html|publisher=ABC7|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=March 28, 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Jeff Clabaugh|title=D.C.’s first cat cafe (yes, a cafe with cats) opens this month|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/blog/top-shelf/2015/06/d-c-s-first-cat-cafe-yes-a-cafe-with-cats-opens.html|website=Washington Business Journal|accessdate=June 14, 2015|date=June 9, 2015}} Through the partnership arrangement, the Humane Society provides vaccinated and vetted cats to Crumbs and Whiskers, which functions as a foster home for the cats until they are adopted.{{cite web|author1=Ellison L Barber,|title=Georgetown Cat Cafe gets approval|url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/local/dc/2015/03/23/georgetown-cat-cafe/70355180/|website=WUSA9|accessdate=April 2, 2015|date=March 24, 2015|quote=On Tuesday morning, a zoning hearing approved to operate Crumbs & Whiskers – a café that specializes in cats. Kanchan Singh said this means a blue building on the corner of Wisconsin and O St NW will officially become the location of her café.}} The Los Angeles café opened on September 30, 2016, and was the first cat café to open in the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]].{{cite web|authors=Megan Moureaux|title=Cats Looking for Furever Homes at LA's First Cat Cafe|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Cats-Looking-Furever-Homes-LA-Cat-Cafe-397474921.html|publisher=NBC Los Angeles|accessdate=January 1, 2017|date=October 18, 2016}}{{cite web|authors=Suzanne Sproul|title=Everything you need to know about LA’s first cat cafe Crumbs & Whiskers|url=http://www.dailynews.com/lifestyle/20160923/everything-you-need-to-know-about-las-first-cat-cafe-crumbs-amp-whiskers|publisher=Los Angeles Daily News|accessdate=January 1, 2017|date=September 23, 2016}} The Los Angeles café is partnered with Karma Rescue, a Los Angeles-based [[animal shelter]] which provides cats for the café. Similar to the Washington D.C. café, the Los Angeles café offers boarding space for the cats until they are adopted. Crumbs and Whiskers uses an online reservation system for scheduling visits and charges a fixed hourly fee.{{cite web|author1=Associated Press|title=DC’s first cat cafe to open in Georgetown June 20|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dcs-first-cat-cafe-to-open-in-georgetown-june-20/2015/06/11/be5cf590-101c-11e5-a0fe-dccfea4653ee_story.html|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=June 14, 2015|date=June 9, 2015}} For safety reasons, children under 13 are not allowed, and young adults between the ages of 13 and 17 must have a form signed by an adult. Crumbs and Whiskers allows customers to begin the application process for adopting one of the cats on site at their cafés.{{cite web|author1=Emily Blomquist|title=Crumbs and Whiskers: D.C.’s first cat cafe.|url=http://www.theeagleonline.com/article/2015/04/crumbs-and-whiskers-dcs-first-cat-cafe|website=The Eagle|accessdate=June 14, 2015|date=June 10, 2015|quote=Customers who decided to purchase any of the cats will start the application process at the cafe.}} ==Startup funding== The business founder, Kanchan Singh, opted to finance the venture by [[crowdfunding]] through a [[Kickstarter]] project with a {{currency|15,000}} target, an amount which she was initially uncertain that she could raise. The Crumbs and Whiskers Kickstarter project reached its funding target less than a day after it launched, and doubled this amount prior to the project deadline. The campaign ended with 705 backers and raised a total of $35,881 for the café.{{cite web|title=Crumbs & Whiskers: Washington DC's Cat Cafe|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/2006072669/crumbs-and-whiskers-washington-dcs-cat-cafe|publisher=Kickstarter|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|group=sources}} '''Sources''' {{reflist|2}} {{Domestic cat|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Cats]] [[Category:Cafés]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Entertainment venues in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Entertainment venues in California]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:2016 establishments in California]] [[Category:Restaurants in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Restaurants in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.comment: /* See also */
revision.text:
[[File:Hermitage cat.jpeg|thumb|One of the Hermitage cats]] The '''Hermitage cats''' ({{lang-ru|Эрмитажные коты}}) are a group of [[cats]] residing in the [[Hermitage Museum]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia. The museum has a press secretary dedicated to the cats,<ref name=BBCRodgers>Rodgers, James. "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7029370.stm Hermitage palace is cat's whiskers]" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiAtzyTB Archive]). [[BBC]]. Friday 5 October 2007. Retrieved on 2 July 2015.</ref> and three people act as caretakers.<ref name=Cole>Cole, Teresa Levonian. "[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/russia/10075304/St-Petersburg-the-cats-of-the-Hermitage.html St Petersburg: the cats of the Hermitage]" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiITTFVE Archive]). ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''. 23 May 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2015.</ref> The cats live in the museum's basement, and they also appear on the embankment and on the square during the summer. In previous eras they roamed throughout the museum galleries.<ref name=Natgeo>"[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/06/090612-cats-video-ap.html Cat "Army" Guards Treasures]" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiDyoCnW Archive]). ''[[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]]''. June 12, 2009. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref>
In 2010 Maria Khaltunen (also "Khaltunin" or "Haltunen")<!--The "Khaltunin" spelling is from ABC News, "Haltunen" is from ''The New Yorker''-->, who directs the museum's cat programme, stated that there were 60 cats on the museum grounds, even though the staff has a joke that officially the museum is only supposed to have 50 cats.<ref name=Marquardt>Marquardt, Alexander. "[http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/International/russias-hermitage-museum-home-artistic-masters-cats/story?id=11218561 St. Petersburg's Hermitage Museum Home to Masters...and Cats]" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiE5oEZQ Archive]). ''[[ABC News]]''. July 30, 2010. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref>
Irina Popovets, who became the head of the cat department, stated that the cats were "as well-known as our collections."<ref>"[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/the-nine-lives-of-russias-hermitage-museum-cats.aspx?pageID=238&nID=91288&NewsCatID=378 The nine lives of Russia’s Hermitage Museum cats]." ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' at ''[[Hurriyet Daily News]]''. November 18, 2015. Retrieved on July 18, 2016.</ref>
In May 2013, the count had grown to 74 cats, of both sexes (but neutered), according to Haltunen.<ref name=Cole/> There are kitchens for preparing their food ("they all have different preferences"), and even a small hospital.<ref name=Cole/>
As of 2013 donations, a €400-per-month payment from the charity Pro Animale, and the sponsorship of [[Royal Canin]] fund the presence of the cats.<ref name=Cole/>
== History == The cats were present in the museum, originally a palace, since the 18th century;<ref name=BBCRodgers/> in 1745, [[Elizabeth of Russia]] ordered cats to be placed in the palace in order to control the mice.<ref name=McGrane>McGrane, Sally. "[http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/russias-museum-cats Russia’s Museum Cats]" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiGPBiwT Archive]). ''[[The New Yorker]]''. September 25, 2012. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref> James Rodgers of the [[BBC]] stated that the belief is that the cats originated from [[Kazan]], a city known for having cats good at catching mice. The cats remained in St. Petersburg except during [[World War II]],<ref name=BBCRodgers/> when the existing cat population was killed. A new group of cats replaced the previous cats since the rat population had increased.<ref name=Marquardt/>
In the late 1990s,<!--About 15 years before 2012 is 1997--> Khaltunen began a programme to care for the cats, which previously lived in poor conditions.<ref name=McGrane/>
As of 2007 the museum began adopting cats needing homes.<ref name=BBCRodgers/>
In 2011, the museum began a "Catfest", a celebration of its cat population. "Catfest" has included cat painting contests and scavenger hunts for children.<ref name=McGrane/>
Beginning in 2015, because of the number of visiting tourists, a website has been set up by the museum for people who may be interested in adopting a cat. “It is an honor to adopt a Hermitage cat,” one potential cat owner was told.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2015/11/hermitage-museum-also-serves-as-cat-rescue-adoption-center/|title=Russia’s Hermitage Museum Is Filled With Cats|date=17 November 2015|publisher=''[[The Daily Observer]]''|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>
== See also == Other cats kept to deter mice in public buildings include: * [[Canadian Parliamentary Cats]] * [[Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office|Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office, United Kingdom]] * [[Tibs the Great]] kept by the Royal Mail in the UK.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * The Hermitage Museum and Maria Haltunen. ''The Hermitage Cats: Treasures from the State Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg''. [[Unicorn Press Limited]], 5 July 2015. {{ISBN|1910065668}}, 9781910065662. [[Google Books]] [https://books.google.de/books?id=dUdErgEACAAJ&dq=Hermitage+cats&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y profile].
==External links== * [http://hermitagecats.ru/ Hermitage Cats] {{ru icon}} * "[http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/videos/hermitage-museum-cats/ Hermitage Museum Cats]" - [[National Geographic Channel]] [[Category:Hermitage Museum]] [[Category:Cats]] [[Category:History of Saint Petersburg]]

revision.text:
{{medref|date=December 2015}} [[File:Unitarian Church Cat Therapy 4.JPG|thumb|right|Therapy cats have cuddled with many hospitals patients, offering comfort and companionship]]
A '''therapy cat''' is a cat trained to help ailing humans in a medically beneficial way to take advantage of the human-animal interaction for purposes of relaxation and healing. A therapy cat provides affection and comfort to people in retirement homes, nursing homes, schools, hospices, and other human service care facilities.
Therapy cats come in all sizes and breeds. The most important characteristic of a therapy cat is its temperament. A good therapy cat must be friendly, patient, confident, gentle, and at ease in all situations. Therapy cats must enjoy human contact and be content to be petted and handled, sometimes clumsily. Cats must demonstrate that loud noises and barking dogs do not bother them.
A therapy cat's primary job is to allow unfamiliar people to make physical contact with it and to enjoy that contact. Children in particular enjoy hugging animals; adults usually enjoy simply petting the cat. The cat might need to be lifted onto, or climb onto, an individual's lap or bed and sit or lie comfortably there. In hospice environments, therapy cats can play a role in palliative care by reducing death anxiety.
Therapy cats have been used as companions to help the recovery and well-being of stroke victims,<ref name=twsN515>{{cite news |author= Linda Wilson Fuoco |title= Pet Tales: Paralyzed therapy cat inspires patients |publisher= Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date= July 24, 2010 |url= http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10205/1074966-62.stm |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> lower [[blood pressure]],<ref name=twsN6567>{{cite news |author= Associated Press |title= Pet therapy for humans who need it most |work= Naperville Sun |date= Aug 4, 2011 |url= http://napervillesun.suntimes.com/lifestyles/3430464-417/therapy-pet-naperville-reading-area.html?print=true |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref><ref name=twsN611>{{cite news |author= Associated Press |title= Even hairless Sphynx cats give patients a warm, fuzzy feeling |publisher= ''USA Today'' |date= December 1, 2009 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/life/lifestyle/pets/2009-12-02-sphynx02_ST_N.htm |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> decrease patient [[anxiety]],<ref name=twsN6567/><ref name=twsN611/> increase sensory stimulation,<ref name=twsN6567/> ward off depression,<ref name=twsN611/> inspire a "sense of purpose",<ref name=twsN6567/> and assist teens at juvenile detention centers<ref name=twsN613/><ref name=twsN612>{{cite news |author= staff writer |title= Jersey City dance school mourns loss of therapy cat |publisher= The Jersey Journal |date= March 4, 2011 |url= http://www.nj.com/hudson/index.ssf/2011/03/jersey_city_dance_school_mourn.html |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> and children with developmental disabilities<ref name=twsN613>{{cite news |author= Associated Press |title= Missing NY therapy cat found |work= The Wall Street Journal |date= January 10, 2012 |url= https://online.wsj.com/article/AP44374f921d6442a994213f920c79193f.html |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref><ref name=twsN612/> and to help children with language, speech and hearing problems.<ref name=twsNre4e>{{cite news |author= SHELBY GRAD |title= Countywide : Show Cats Just Purrfect for Therapy |work= Los Angeles Times |date= June 4, 1993 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1993-06-04/local/me-43205_1_international-cat-show |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> Some [[nursing homes]] have therapy cats that are used as companions to their [[elderly]] residents. Therapy cats are also sometimes used in hospitals to relax children who are staying there.<ref>{{cite web|author=webmaster |url=http://www.catsplay.com/thedailycat/2002-02-18/mind_relationships/therapy_cats/therapy_cats.html |title=The Special Love of Therapy Cats : Feline Relationships : Your Cat's Mind |publisher=Catsplay.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-20}}</ref> There have been arguments made that therapy animals can work as well as or better than conventional [[pharmaceutical]] medicine for helping people relax,{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} lowering stress levels and blood pressure decreases,<ref name=twsN611/> causing the heart rate to slow down.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} According to one report, the cats can help children and teens with special needs to "feel relaxed", and that the human-cat communication is beneficial.<ref name=twsN612/> One researcher reviewing 25 studies found positive effects of pets on patients in [[nursing home]]s, and found evidence that the animals helped patients be more alert, smile more often, and that the presence of the pets helped physically aggressive patients to calm down and allow other humans to be near them.<ref name=twsN6567/>
==See also== * [[Animal-assisted therapy]] * [[Oscar (therapy cat)]] * [[Service animal]] * [[Service dog]] * [[Therapy dog]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.animallaw.info/topic/table-state-assistance-animal-laws Assistance Animal State Laws] - Michigan State University * [https://www.tsa.gov/travel/special-procedures Disabilities and Medical Conditions] - TSA (Transport Security Administration)

revision.comment: Undid revision 798090064 by [[Special:Contributions/216.226.180.45|216.226.180.45]] ([[User talk:216.226.180.45|talk]]) undo unexplained removal
revision.text:
[[Cat]]s hunt small prey, and both [[feral cat|feral]] and [[domestication|domesticated]] cats prey on wildlife. This is sometimes seen as a desirable phenomenon, such as in the case of [[barn cat]]s and other cats kept for the purposes of pest control. In other cases, the effect of cats on wildlife is met with concern.
==Mice and rats== For thousands of years, cats have been known for their ability to hunt mice and rats and keep their populations under control. This ability is understood as the reason cats became domesticated.<ref name="Temple Grandin">Grandin, Temple and Johnson, Catherine (2009) ''Animals Make Us Human: Creating the Best Life for Animals'', Mariner Books, {{ISBN|9780151014897}}.</ref> {{rp|68}} The relationship was more of convenience (or mutualistic) than dependence: "Cats killed mice and rats, and humans provided lots of mice and rats to kill since mice and rats lived in human settlements."<ref name="Temple Grandin"/>{{rp|68}} A 2014 study examining 5,300 years of cat remains in an agricultural village of Quanhucun, [[China]], provides early evidence of this dynamic, where cats protected grain stores by eating rodents.<ref name="Ancient cat bones">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/dec/17/ancient-cat-bone-research-china-domestic-pet | title=Ancient Chinese cat bones shake up domestication theory | newspaper=The Guardian | date=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="Hu 2014 on Cat domestication"> {{cite journal|doi= 10.1073/pnas.1311439110|title= Earliest evidence for commensal processes of cat domestication|journal= Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume= 111|pages= 116–120|year= 2013|last1= Hu|first1= Y.|last2= Hu|first2= S.|last3= Wang|first3= W.|last4= Wu|first4= X.|last5= Marshall|first5= F. B.|last6= Chen|first6= X.|last7= Hou|first7= L.|last8= Wang|first8= C.|pmid=24344279|pmc=3890806}}</ref>
If they are well-fed, [[farm cat]]s are more dependable as effective ratters, as they are less likely to stray or hunt further afield.<ref name="Tabor Wild Life">Tabor, Roger (1983) ''The Wild Life of the Domestic Cat''. Arrow Books. {{ISBN|0099312107}}.</ref>{{rp|110}} Cats are wary of adult rats, given their size,<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|111}} but are particularly adept at hunting young rats.<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|110}}
In 2002, feral cats introduced to a flower market in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], were noted to have helped lower rat populations.<ref name="Beverly Hills Rats">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/17/us/up-down-in-and-out-in-beverly-hills-rats.html | title=Up, Down, In and Out in Beverly Hills: Rats | first=Charlie | last=LeDuff | newspaper=The New York Times | date=17 September 2002}}</ref> In [[Chicago]]'s 47th Ward, feral cats were introduced in 2012 to help the city deal with the rat problem there.<ref>[http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/06/28/north-sides-47th-ward-using-feral-cats-to-catch-rats/ "North Side’s 47th Ward Using Feral Cats To Catch Rats"], CBS Chicago, 28 June 2012.</ref>
Efforts to eradicate feral cats in [[Ventura, California]], were noted in 2002 to have resulted in increasing numbers of rats, which were being monitored for health problems such as [[bubonic plague]].<ref name="Beverly Hills Rats"/><ref name="LA rodents have field day">{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/sep/09/local/me-rats9 | title=With the Cats Away, Beachfront Rodents Have a Field Day | first=Jessica | last=Blanchard | newspaper=Los Angeles Times | date=9 September 2002}}</ref>
==Birds== A 2013 study by Scott R. Loss and others of the [[Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute]] and the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] suggested that free-ranging domestic cats (mostly unowned) are the top human-caused threat to wildlife in the United States, killing an estimated 1.3 to 4 billion birds and 6.3 to 22.3 billion mammals annually.<ref name="Loss 2013">{{cite journal|url=http://www.alleycat.org/document.doc?id=634|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904132317/http://www.alleycat.org/document.doc?id=634|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-09-04|title=The impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United States|journal=Nature Communications|volume=4|pages=1396|doi=10.1038/ncomms2380|pmid=23360987|year=2013|last1=Loss|first1=Scott R.|last2=Will|first2=Tom|last3=Marra|first3=Peter P.}}</ref><ref name='BBCNews'>{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21236690 | title = Cats killing billions of animals in the US | accessdate = 12 February 2013 | last = Morelle | first = Rebecca | date = 29 January 2013 | work = BBC News}}</ref> These figures were much higher than previous estimates for the U.S.<ref name="Loss 2013"/>{{rp|2}} Unspecified species of birds native to the U.S. and mammals including [[mouse|mice]], [[shrew]]s, [[vole]]s, [[squirrel]]s and [[rabbit]]s were considered most likely to be preyed upon by cats.<ref name="Loss 2013"/>{{rp|4}}
Perhaps the first U.S. study that pointed to predation by cats on wildlife as a concern was ornithologist [[Edward Howe Forbush]]'s 1916 report for the Massachusetts State Board of Agriculture, ''The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It''.<ref>Edward Howe Forbush, [https://archive.org/details/domesticcatbirdk00forbrich "The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It"], Commonwealth of Massachusetts, State Board of Agriculture, Economic Biology Bulletin 42, 1916.</ref>
U.K. biologist and cat behaviour expert Roger Tabor states that "studies from all around the world have found that cats catch relatively few birds compared to small mammals."<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior">Tabor, Roger (2003) ''Understanding Cat Behavior''. David & Charles Ltd. {{ISBN|9780715315897}}.</ref>{{rp|135}} The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation "is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide."<ref name="Are cats causing bird declines?"> [http://www.rspb.org.uk/advice/gardening/unwantedvisitors/cats/birddeclines.aspx "Are cats causing bird declines?"] The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, accessed 23 June 2014.</ref> Moreover, city cats have smaller ranges. In his research, Tabor found "the average annual catch of the average London cat to be two items instead of the fourteen of a village cat."<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior"/>{{rp|135}} Tabor comments about some of the challenges of stalking birds for cats: "From the cat's point of view not only do birds not play fair by flying and having eyes that can see beyond the back of their heads, but they can positively cheat by using loud alarm calls and throw the cat's chances of catching any others."<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|123}}
Island settings pose particular challenges for wildlife. A 2001 study identified cats alone as responsible for the plight of some island bird species, such as the [[Townsend's shearwater]], [[socorro dove]], and the [[Marquesan ground dove]].<ref name="Endangered birds"> {{cite book|last=Collar|first=N. J.|title=Endangered Birds|url=http://people.ds.cam.ac.uk/cns26/NJC/Papers/Endangered_birds.pdf |volume=2|year=2001|publisher=Academic Press|location=New York|page=400}} in ''Encyclopedia of Biodiversity''</ref><ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|400}} The same study identified the greatest cause of endangerment of birds as habitat loss and degradation, with at least 52% of endangered birds affected,<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|399}} while [[introduced species]] on islands, such as domestic cats, [[rat]]s and [[Mustelidae|mustelids]],<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|403}} affected only 6% of endangered birds.<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|399}} Other studies caution that removing domestic cats from islands can have unintended consequences, as increasing rat populations can put native bird<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15998496 | doi=10.1016/j.bulm.2004.12.002 | volume=67 | title=Cats protecting birds revisited | journal=Bull Math Biol | pages=1081–106 | last1 = Fan | first1 = M | last2 = Kuang | first2 = Y | last3 = Feng | first3 = Z}}</ref> and mammal species<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hanna | first1 = Emily | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = | title = Island mammal extinctions are determined by interactive effects of life history, island biogeography and mesopredator suppression | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/geb.12103/abstract | journal = Global Ecology and Biogeography | volume = 23| issue = | pages = 395–404| doi=10.1111/geb.12103}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/conservation/feral-cats-help-some-endangered-mammals-survive-report-says-20130829-2ssvt.html | title=Feral cats help some endangered mammals survive, report says | first=Gerald | last=Popkin | newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=29 August 2013}}</ref> at risk.
==Impact by location==
===Australia=== {{See also|Cats in Australia}}
Cats in Australia have been found to have European origins.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Population Origins and Expansion of Feral Cats in Australia|last = Spencer|first = Peter B.S.|date = 9 November 2015|journal = American Genetic Association|doi = 10.1093/jhered/esv095|volume=107|pages=104–114}}</ref> This is important to note because of their effect on native species. Feral cats in Australia have been linked to the decline and extinction of various native animals. They have been shown to cause a significant impact on ground nesting birds and small native mammals.<ref name="Dickman">{{cite book|last1 = Dickman|first1 = Chris|title = Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna|publisher = The Director of National Parks and Wildlife – Australian Nature Conservation Agency – Institute of Wildlife Research|date = May 1996|url = http://secure.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/impacts-feral-cats.pdf|accessdate = 11 February 2013|isbn = 0-642-21379-8|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304040904/http://secure.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/impacts-feral-cats.pdf|archivedate = 4 March 2016|df = }}</ref>
Feral cats have also hampered any attempts to re-introduce threatened species back into areas where they have become extinct as the cats have hunted and killed the newly released animals.<ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/pestsweeds/TheThreatOfFeralCats.htm The Threat Of FeralCats]. Environment.nsw.gov.au (28 October 2011). Retrieved on 5 May 2013.</ref> Numerous Australian environmentalists claim the feral cat has been an ecological disaster in Australia, inhabiting most ecosystems except dense [[rainforest]], and being implicated in the [[extinction]] of several [[marsupial]] and [[Placentalia|placental]] mammal [[species]].<ref name="Interactions">{{cite journal | title = Interactions between feral cats, foxes, native carnivores, and rabbits in Australia | journal = CSIRO Sustainable Ecosystems / Arthur Rylah Institute for Environmental Research | date = Sep 2004 | authors = Robley, A. Reddiex, B. Arthur T. Pech R. Forsyth, D. | url = http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/interaction.pdf | accessdate = 12 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317105943/http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/interaction.pdf|archivedate=17 March 2011}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== {{See also|Cats in New Zealand}}
The fauna of [[New Zealand]] has evolved in isolation for millions of years without the presence of mammals (apart from a few bat species). Consequently, birds dominated the niches occupied by mammals and many became flightless. The introduction of mammals after settlement by [[Māori people|Māori]] from about the 12th century had a huge effect on the indigenous [[biodiversity]]. [[Europe]]an explorers and settlers brought cats on their ships and the presence of feral cats were recorded from the latter decades of the 19th century.<ref>King, Carolyn (1984) ''Immigrant Killers''. Auckland: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-558121-0}}</ref> It is estimated that feral cats have been responsible for the extinction of six endemic bird species and over 70 localised subspecies as well as depleting bird and lizard species.<ref>{{Cite conference | authors = Eason, Charles T.; Morgan, David R. and Clapperton, B. Kay | title = Toxic bait and baiting strategies for feral cats | publisher = Proceedings of the Fifteenth Vertebrate Pest Conference 1992 | year = 1992 | location = University of Nebraska – Lincoln | url = http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1024&context=vpc15}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]], The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation "is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide. The article goes on to say, "This may be surprising, but many millions of birds die naturally every year, mainly through starvation, disease, or other forms of predation. There is evidence that cats tend to take weak or sickly birds".
"Those bird species that have undergone the most serious population declines in the UK (such as [[Alauda|skylarks]], [[Eurasian tree sparrow|tree sparrows]] and [[corn bunting]]s) rarely encounter cats, so cats cannot be causing their declines. Research shows that these declines are usually caused by habitat change or loss, particularly on farmland."<ref name="Are cats causing bird declines?"/> This evidence is despite the common practice in the U.K. of allowing owned cats access to the outdoors,<ref>"In the UK, the vast majority of pet cats have free access to the outside world, or are at least allowed to go outside unsupervised for large parts of the day." [http://www.pets4homes.co.uk/pet-advice/a-world-of-difference-how-cat-ownership-in-america-differs-to-the-uk.html "A world of difference – How cat ownership in America differs to the UK"], Pets4Homes, accessed 1 September 2014.</ref> which is recommended to prevent feline obesity (p. 138) and behavior problems and other health problems arising from confinement stress (p. 121).<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior"/>
[[SongBird Survival]] considers that "The prevailing line that “there is no scientific evidence that predation by cats is having any impact on bird populations in UK” is simply no longer tenable.",<ref>https://www.songbird-survival.org.uk/cats.html</ref> noting "No study has ever examined the impact of cats on songbirds at the population level; Evidence shows that the recovering sparrowhawk population in the 1970-80s resulted in the decline of some songbird populations; Cats kill around 3 times as many songbirds as sparrowhawks; The mere presence of cats near birds’ nests was found to decrease provision of food by a third while the resultant mobbing clamour from parent birds led in turn to increased nest predation by crows and magpies; [and that] It is therefore far more likely that cats have an even greater impact on songbird populations than sparrowhawks"
[[Sir David Attenborough]] in his Christmas Day edition of [[BBC Radio 4]] programme Tweet Of The Day said ""Cats kill an extraordinarily high number of birds in British gardens,".<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/dec/10/cats-killing-birds-gardens-david-attenborough</ref> Asked whether cat owners should buy bell collars for their pets at Christmas, he replied: "That would be good for the robins, yes."
===Islands===
====Consequences of introduction==== [[File:Xenicus lyalli.jpg|right|thumb|[[Lyall's wren]] became extinct within two years of the introduction of cats to [[Stephens Island, New Zealand|Stephens Island]].]]
Many islands host [[island tameness|ecologically naive]] animal species. That is, animals that do not have predator responses for dealing with predators such as cats.<ref name="Moors">Moors, P.J.; Atkinson, I.A.E. (1984). "Predation on seabirds by introduced animals, and factors affecting its severity" in ''Status and Conservation of the World's Seabirds''. Cambridge: ICBP. {{ISBN|0-946888-03-5}}.</ref> Feral cats [[introduced species|introduced]] to such islands have had a devastating impact on these islands' [[biodiversity]].<ref name="NYT"/>
They have been implicated in the extinction of several species and local extinctions, such as the [[hutia]]s from the [[Caribbean]], the [[Guadalupe storm petrel]] from the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast of [[Mexico]], and [[Lyall's wren]]. In a statistical study, they were a significant cause for the extinction of 40% of the species studied.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/02/magazine/02cats-v--birds-t.html?em&ex=1196830800&en=4328122ab745ee4d&ei=5087%0A | work=The New York Times | title=Kill the Cat That Kills the Bird? | first=Bruce | last=Barcott | date=2 December 2007}}</ref> Moors and Atkinson wrote, in 1984, "No other alien predator has had such a universally damaging effect."<ref name="Moors"/>
Feral cats, along with rabbits, some sea birds, and [[sheep]], form the entire large animal population of the remote [[Kerguelen Islands]] in the southern [[Indian Ocean]]. Although exotic mammals form the bulk of their diet, cats' impact on seabirds is very important.<ref name="Kerguelen">{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/s00300-002-0424-5 | title=The diet of feral cats (''Felis catus'' L.) at ﬁve sites on the Grande Terre, Kerguelen archipelago | author=Pontier, D., L. Say, F. Debias, J. Bried, J. Thioulouse, T. Micol & E. Natoli|url=http://pbil.univ-lyon1.fr/JTHome/ref/DPetal2002.pdf | year=2002 }}</ref>
====Restoration==== Because of the damage cats cause in islands and some ecosystems, many conservationists working in the field of [[island restoration]] have worked to remove feral cats. (Island restoration involves the removal of introduced species and reintroducing native species.) As of 2004, 48 islands have had their feral cat populations eradicated, including [[New Zealand]]'s network of offshore island bird reserves<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.issg.org/pdf/publications/Island_Invasives/pdfHQprint/1Campbell.pdf|title=A review of feral cat eradication on islands|doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2004.00442.x|year=2004|last1=Nogales|first1=Manuel|last2=Martin|first2=Aurelio|last3=Tershy|first3=Bernie R.|last4=Donlan|first4=C. Josh|last5=Veitch|first5=Dick|last6=Puerta|first6=Nestor|last7=Wood|first7=Bill|last8=Alonso|first8=Jesus|journal=Conservation Biology|volume=18|issue=2|pages=310–319}}</ref> and Australia's [[Macquarie Island]].
Larger projects have also been undertaken, including their complete removal from [[Ascension Island]]. The cats, introduced in the 19th century, caused a collapse in populations of nesting [[seabird]]s. The project to remove them from the island began in 2002, and the island was cleared of cats by 2004. Since then, seven species of seabird that had not nested on the island for 100 years have returned.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com/search?q=ascension Cat eradication from Ascension Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com (2014-01-23). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref>
In some cases, the removal of cats had unintended consequences. An example is Macquarie Island, where the removal of cats caused an explosion in the number of rabbits, rats, and mice that harm native seabirds<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/environment/up-against-rats-rabbits-and-costs/2007/04/11/1175971183257.html?page=fullpage | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Up against rats, rabbits and costs | date=12 April 2007}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060720104709/http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200607/s1687413.htm Fears for sub-antarctic island plagued by rabbits]. ABC News (15 July 2006).</ref><ref>Draper, Michelle and La Canna, Xavier (14 January 2009) [https://web.archive.org/web/20110706111235/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=718505 Cat kill devastates Macquarie Island]. Nine News</ref> even if the eradication was positioned within an integrated pest management framework.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com.es/2013/05/controversy-on-cats-eradication-on.html Controversy on feral cat removal on Macquarie Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com.es (2013-05-14). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref> The removal of the rats and rabbits was scheduled for 2007 and it could take up to seven years and cost $24 million.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070812004625/http://www.parks.tas.gov.au/macquarie/rabbitsfaq.html Macquarie Island World Heritage Area. Plan for the Eradication of Rabbits and Rodents on Macquarie Island]. Parks and Wildlife Service, Tasmania. parks.tas.gov.au</ref>

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2016}}
{{merge to|Felidae|discuss=Talk:Felidae#Merger proposal|date=September 2016}}A '''pet exotic feline''', also called '''pet wild cat''' or '''pet non-domestic cat''', is a member of the [[Felidae]] family (excluding the [[Cat|house cat]] and hybrids thereof) kept as an [[exotic pet]].
== Definition and differentiations == Hybrids of the domestic cat with non-domestic species (e. g. the [[Bengal cat]] or the [[Savannah cat]]) are not normally considered '''wild cats'''. While this distinction is often overlooked in the media and in the public eye, such cat breeds (especially the F5 and subsequent generations) are much closer to the domestic cat in terms of housing and husbandry requirements, behavior, and legality.
Unlike many other exotic pet species, wild cats usually cannot be kept indoors and require a large outdoor enclosure. This blurs the distinction between a wild cat being kept as an exotic pet and a private animal collection or menagerie. Usually, an enclosure meant for a pet exotic cat is built adjacent to the house in order to give the animal access into the living quarters.
[[Lion taming|Tame big cats]] kept by [[Animal training|animal trainers]] (e. g. in circuses, private zoos or the film animal industry) are commonly mistaken for exotic pets. While the husbandry conditions and handling might be similar to a purely private setting, the common definition of a [[pet]] only includes animals kept for companionship or pleasure. Professional holders, breeders, or exhibitors do not meet this definition.
== History == Exotic felines have a long tradition in human care. The ancient Egyptians kept servals<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.domesticatedservals.com/|title=Domesticated Servals|website=www.domesticatedservals.com|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> in the same role as the African Wildcat (the wild ancestor of modern house cats). [[Cheetah]]s have also been kept throughout the world, both as companions and as hunting aides.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cheetahs-rock.de/index-englisch.htm|title=Cheetah's Rock|website=www.cheetahs-rock.de|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> Caracals have also been tamed and trained, primarily by Arabian and Asian rulers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.caracal-rock.com/index-englisch.htm|title=Caracal Rock|website=www.caracal-rock.com|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> Other large cats sometimes were also kept as companions, but were mostly limited to menageries owned by royal families.
== Species kept as exotic pets == In general, small cat species are more commonly kept as exotic pets than larger ones. [[Big cat]]s are substantially more expensive to maintain, pose a greater danger when being handled in direct contact, and may not always remain handleable when fully grown. This typically limits their keeping to professional animal trainers and zoo settings.
=== Servals and caracals === [[Serval]]s and [[caracal]]s have the longest history as human companions. Part of their popularity can be attributed to the fact that they readily hybridize with domestic cats. The resulting crosses ([[Savannah cat|savannahs]] and caracats) inherit traits of both the domestic cat and the wild species. <ref> https://caracats.wordpress.com/ </ref>
=== Lynxes and bobcats === Nearly all species of the [[Lynx]] genus (with the exception of the Iberian lynx) are kept as exotic pets. Unlike other small cat species, they are not known to hybridize with the domestic cat.
=== Ocelots === This species enjoyed some popularity as an exotic pet in the 50s and 60s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://allaboutocelots.wordpress.com/2015/12/25/ocelots-as-pets/|title=Ocelots as pets|date=2015-12-25|website=all about ocelots|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> The passage of the Endangered Species Act in the USA effectively ended their keeping outside of zoological facilities due to interstate animal movement restrictions. Their popularity is also limited by their comparatively high aggression.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phoenixexotics.org/caresheet/ocelot|title=Care Sheet - Ocelot {{!}} Phoenix Exotic Wildlife Association|website=www.phoenixexotics.org|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> No hybrids with domestic cats are known.
=== Pumas === While being considered small cats taxonomically, pumas are comparable in size to some of the big cats. They are typically less aggressive and more affectionate than big cats, which has led to some popularity as exotic pets.
=== Cheetahs === The cheetah has a long history as a human companion. However, difficulties in breeding prevented this species from becoming a widespread exotic pet in modern times.
== See also == * [[Exotic pet]] * [[Feline Conservation Federation]] * [[Lion taming]]
== References == {{reflist}}
