revision.text:
[[File:Aging-1.jpg|alt=Ovulation |thumb|400x400px|Ovulation ]]{{Infobox medical condition | Reproduction = | Ovulation = }} '''[[Ovulation]]''' occurs at the [[ovary]] surface and is described as the process in which an [[oocyte]] (female germ cell) is released from the follicle. Ovulation is a non-deleterious 'inflammatory response' which is initiated by a [[Luteinizing hormone|Luteinising Hormone]] (LH) surge<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=J. S.|last2=Hedin|first2=L.|date=1988|title=Molecular aspects of hormone action in ovarian follicular development, ovulation, and luteinization|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3288100|journal=Annual Review of Physiology|volume=50|pages=441–463|doi=10.1146/annurev.ph.50.030188.002301|issn=0066-4278|pmid=3288100}}</ref>. The mechanism of ovulation varies between species. In humans the ovulation process occurs around day 14 of the menstrual cycle, this can also be referred to as 'cyclical spontaneous ovulation'. However the monthly menstruation process is typically linked to humans and primates<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Strassmann|first=B. I.|date=June 1996|title=The evolution of endometrial cycles and menstruation|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8693059|journal=The Quarterly Review of Biology|volume=71|issue=2|pages=181–220|issn=0033-5770|pmid=8693059}}</ref>, all other animal species ovulate by various other mechanisms.
'''Spontaneous ovulation''' is the ovulatory process in which the maturing ovarian follicles secrete ovarian steroids to generate pulsatile [[GnRH]] (the neuropeptide which controls all vertebrate reproductive function) release into the median eminence (the area which connects the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland) to ultimately cause a pre-ovulatory LH surge. Spontaneously ovulating species go through [[Menstrual cycle|menstrual cycles]] and are fertile at certain times based on what part of the cycle they are in. Species in which the females are spontaneous ovulators include rats, mice, guinea pigs, sheep, monkeys, and women<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Bakker|first=J.|last2=Baum|first2=M. J.|date=July 2000|title=Neuroendocrine regulation of GnRH release in induced ovulators|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10882541|journal=Frontiers in Neuroendocrinology|volume=21|issue=3|pages=220–262|doi=10.1006/frne.2000.0198|issn=0091-3022|pmid=10882541}}</ref>.
'''Induced ovulation''' is the process in which the pre-ovulatory LH surge and therefore ovulation is induced by some component of coitus e.g receipt of genital stimulation. Usually spontaneous steroid-induced LH surges are not observed in induced ovulator species throughout their reproductive cycles, which indicates that GnRH release is absent or reduced due to lack of positive feedback action from steroid hormones. However, by contradiction some spontaneously ovulating species can occasionally undergo mating-induced preovulatory LH surges. Species in which the females are induced ovulators include cats, rabbits, ferrets, and camels<ref name=":0" />. In 1985, Chen et al., used Bactrian camels to investigate the factor(s) that induce ovulation during breeding season. They monitored the camel ovaries for ovulation by rectal palpation following insemination of semen samples. Chen et al., concluded that in this particular camel species ovulation was induced by the seminal plasma, and not by the spermatozoa<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=B. X.|last2=Yuen|first2=Z. X.|last3=Pan|first3=G. W.|date=1985-07-01|title=Semen-induced ovulation in the bactrian camel (Camelus bactrianus)|url=http://www.reproduction-online.org/content/74/2/335|journal=Journal of Reproduction and Fertility|language=en|volume=74|issue=2|pages=335–339|doi=10.1530/jrf.0.0740335|issn=1470-1626|pmid=3900379}}</ref>.
== Evolution == Although the evolution of these two types of ovulation is not well understood, the type of ovulation that would be advantageous in some species can be understood by looking at social groups. Animals that have large, complex social groups benefit from spontaneous ovulation as only the best males get to breed with females. If there are little males suitable for breeding it makes sense to spread out the times at which females are fertile, therefore increasing the proportion in which conception occurs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Conaway|first=C. H.|date=June 1971|title=Ecological adaptation and mammalian reproduction|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/5000279|journal=Biology of Reproduction|volume=4|issue=3|pages=239–247|issn=0006-3363|pmid=5000279}}</ref> This does not explain the evolution of ovulation in all species however, for example some species appear to show estrus synchronisation.
== Mechanism == In spontaneous ovulators, [[estrogen]] secreted by the follicles as they grow and mature affects the release of GnRH, and therefore causes an LH surge.
Ovulation is triggered in induced ovulators by a LH surge from the anterior pituitary, which appears to be independent of GnRH release, and is induced during mating. Animals this has been recorded in include rabbits, voles, ferrets and camels.<ref name=":0" /> In some species such as the ferret the duration of intromission has no effect on the LH surge, whereas in other species such as the cat these are related and higher levels of LH were produced by mating multiple times. In many species, for a LH surge to occur, little intromission is required.
The pathways in which information reaches the brain and causes GnRH release are not understood well, however midbrain and brainstem noradrenergic neurones appear to be activated in response to intromission during mating. These neurones then go on to stimulate the mediobasal hypothalamic to release GnRH from the median eminence. <ref name=":0" />Most experiments on GnRH and LH release have been focused on spontaneous ovulators, however there have been studies completed on some induced ovulators - rabbit and ferret. From this, it appears that norepinephrine facilitates GnRH release in the rabbit and ferret and the [[Locus coeruleus|locus coereuleus]] which is the part of the brain involved in conveying genital-somatosensory information to the GnRH neurones<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spies|first=H. G.|last2=Pau|first2=K. Y.|last3=Yang|first3=S. P.|date=February 1997|title=Coital and estrogen signals: a contrast in the preovulatory neuroendocrine networks of rabbits and rhesus monkeys|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9116126|journal=Biology of Reproduction|volume=56|issue=2|pages=310–319|issn=0006-3363|pmid=9116126}}</ref>. Other subsances that have similar effects include [[neuropeptide Y]].
== Species == Many species which have been found to be induced ovulators and the reasons for this are not always clear. However, one possible reason is that induced ovulation could provide a better reproductive potential for those species that typically have shorter life spans and less encounters resulting in lower mating opportunites throughout their lifetime.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/openurl?sid=gale:&aufirst=Jestina&aulast=Katandukila&atitle=Pattern%20of%20ovulation%20in%20the%20East%20African%20root%20rat%20(Tachyoryctes%20splendens)%20from%20Tanzania:%20induced%20or%20spontaneous%20ovulator?&date=2016-05&genre=article&issn=00084301&issue=5&pages=345&spage=345&title=Canadian%20Journal%20of%20Zoology&volume=94&vid=44UOE_VU2&institution=44UOE&url_ctx_val=&url_ctx_fmt=null&isSerivcesPage=true|title=https://ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/openurl?sid=gale:&aufirst=Jestina&aulast=Katandukila&atitle=Pattern%20of%20ovulation%20in%20the%20East%20African%20root%20rat%20(Tachyoryctes%20splendens)%20from%20Tanzania:%20induced%20or%20spontaneous%20ovulator?&date=2016-05&genre=article&issn=00084301&issue=5&pages=345&spage=345&title=Canadian%20Journal%20of%20Zoology&volume=94&vid=44UOE_VU2&institution=44UOE&url_ctx_val=&url_ctx_fmt=null&isSerivcesPage=true|website=ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-27}}</ref>
Rodents such as [[Ferret|ferrets]], [[Mouse|mice]] and [[Rat|rats]] are known induced ovulators. In Rats the East African Root Rat and the Cape-Dune, Natal, Highvield and Blind Mole Rats are known induced ovulators. These species require mating to stimulate the vagina and cervix, resulting in ovulation in the Females. The East African Root Rat has been found to have small spines on its penis which are also thought to contribute to this stimulation of induced ovulation. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/openurl?sid=gale:&aufirst=Jestina&aulast=Katandukila&atitle=Pattern%20of%20ovulation%20in%20the%20East%20African%20root%20rat%20(Tachyoryctes%20splendens)%20from%20Tanzania:%20induced%20or%20spontaneous%20ovulator?&date=2016-05&genre=article&issn=00084301&issue=5&pages=345&spage=345&title=Canadian%20Journal%20of%20Zoology&volume=94&vid=44UOE_VU2&institution=44UOE&url_ctx_val=&url_ctx_fmt=null&isSerivcesPage=true|title=https://ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/openurl?sid=gale:&aufirst=Jestina&aulast=Katandukila&atitle=Pattern%20of%20ovulation%20in%20the%20East%20African%20root%20rat%20(Tachyoryctes%20splendens)%20from%20Tanzania:%20induced%20or%20spontaneous%20ovulator?&date=2016-05&genre=article&issn=00084301&issue=5&pages=345&spage=345&title=Canadian%20Journal%20of%20Zoology&volume=94&vid=44UOE_VU2&institution=44UOE&url_ctx_val=&url_ctx_fmt=null&isSerivcesPage=true|website=ed-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-27}}</ref>
Mice are also thought to be induced ovulators. Studies have found that the [[Luteinizing hormone|Lutenising Hormone]] (LH) is crucial to bring about the induced ovulation. Disruption in LH surges in the mice and knockout of the [[Progesterone]] receptor (progesterone is known to help maintain a pregnancy) results in lowered fertility of the mice. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stephens|first=Shannon B. Z.|last2=Tolson|first2=Kristen P.|last3=Rouse|first3=Melvin L.|last4=Poling|first4=Matthew C.|last5=Hashimoto-Partyka|first5=Minako K.|last6=Mellon|first6=Pamela L.|last7=Kauffman|first7=Alexander S.|date=September 2015|title=Absent Progesterone Signaling in Kisspeptin Neurons Disrupts the LH Surge and Impairs Fertility in Female Mice|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26076042|journal=Endocrinology|volume=156|issue=9|pages=3091–3097|doi=10.1210/en.2015-1300|issn=1945-7170|pmc=PMC4541622|pmid=26076042}}</ref>
The [[Koala]] species are a lesser known induced ovulatory. The Koalas require mating in which the presence of ejaculated semen is needed to stimulate the female to produce a LH surge (which would cause ovulation of a follicle). Unlike many other animals, simply being in the presence of a male koala is not enough to induce ovulation itself, and nor is vaginal stimulation on its own sufficient to cause induced ovulation to occur. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnston|first=S. D.|last2=O'Callaghan|first2=P.|last3=Nilsson|first3=K.|last4=Tzipori|first4=G.|last5=Curlewis|first5=J. D.|date=2004-11-01|title=Semen-induced luteal phase and identification of a LH surge in the koala (Phascolarctos cinereus)|url=http://www.reproduction-online.org/content/128/5/629|journal=Reproduction|language=en|volume=128|issue=5|pages=629–634|doi=10.1530/rep.1.00300|issn=1470-1626|pmid=15509709}}</ref>
The presence of koala semen in female koalas is known to be able to cause induced ovulation on its own, however only in just under 50% of the subjects tested but statistical [[Student's t-test|t tests]] confirmed this to be significant. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnston|first=S. D.|last2=O'Callaghan|first2=P.|last3=Nilsson|first3=K.|last4=Tzipori|first4=G.|last5=Curlewis|first5=J. D.|date=2004-11-01|title=Semen-induced luteal phase and identification of a LH surge in the koala (Phascolarctos cinereus)|url=http://www.reproduction-online.org/content/128/5/629|journal=Reproduction|language=en|volume=128|issue=5|pages=629–634|doi=10.1530/rep.1.00300|issn=1470-1626|pmid=15509709}}</ref>
[[Cat|Cats]] are another widely known induced ovulator. After mating, the LH levels in female cats surge and the time to ovulation can be predicted to occur between 1-2 days later. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shille|first=V. M.|last2=Munrot|first2=Coralie|last3=Farmer|first3=Susan Walker|last4=Papkoff|first4=H.|last5=Stabenfeld|first5=G. H.|date=1983-09-01|title=Ovarian and endocrine responses in the cat after coitus|url=http://www.reproduction-online.org/content/69/1/29|journal=Journal of Reproduction and Fertility|language=en|volume=69|issue=1|pages=29–39|doi=10.1530/jrf.0.0690029|issn=1470-1626|pmid=6684161}}</ref>
[[Goat|Goats]] too have been found to be induced ovulators. A 1984 study saw [[LHRH]] injections were able to cause ovulation in goats that were of sexual maturity and already in [[oestrus]]. These injections had no influence on goats that were not in oestrus and could be because there is reduced sensitivity to LH and FSH receptors in the non oestrus stages of the cycle so the LHRH may not have been able to induce a great enough response. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mizinga|first=K. M.|last2=Verma|first2=O. P.|date=1984-03-01|title=LHRH — Induced ovulation and fertility of anestrous goats|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0093691X84904059|journal=Theriogenology|volume=21|issue=3|pages=435–446|doi=10.1016/0093-691X(84)90405-9}}</ref>
[[Wolverine|Wolverines]] are other known induced ovulators which require physical mating to cause ovulation. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mead|first=Rodney A.|last2=Bowles|first2=Mark|last3=Starypan|first3=Greg|last4=Jones|first4=Mike|date=1993-01-01|title=Evidence for pseudopregnancy and induced ovulation in captive wolverines (Gulo gulo)|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/zoo.1430120405/abstract|journal=Zoo Biology|language=en|volume=12|issue=4|pages=353–358|doi=10.1002/zoo.1430120405|issn=1098-2361}}</ref>
[[Horse|Horses]] are induced ovulators and studies using combinations of PGF2alpa analogues, Lipsostiol, d-cloprostenol and hCG were able to artificially induce ovulation in this species though these neural pathways. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kuhl|first=Juliane|last2=Aurich|first2=Jörg|last3=Aurich|first3=Christine|date=2017-10-01|title=Effects of the Prostaglandin F2α Analogues Cloprostenol and Luprostiol in Combination With hCG on Synchronization of Estrus and Ovulation in Mares|url=http://www.j-evs.com/article/S0737-0806(17)30088-6/fulltext|journal=Journal of Equine Veterinary Science|language=English|volume=57|pages=67–70|doi=10.1016/j.jevs.2017.07.004|issn=0737-0806}}</ref>
Many bear species are able to have induced ovulation including the [[Grizzly bear]], Black [[Bear]] and the [[Polar bear]] where both the presence of a male and mating itself are requirements for induced ovulation. However, there are some suggestions that mating is not as strict a requirement for ovulation in bears. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chang|first=Geng-Ruei|last2=Yang|first2=Chieh-Chung|last3=Hsu|first3=Son-Haur|last4=Lin|first4=Chang|last5=Chiu|first5=Chun-Lung|last6=Chan|first6=Fang-Tse|last7=Mao|first7=Frank Chiahung|title=Fecal Reproductive Steroid Profiles for Monitoring Reproductive Patterns in Female Formosan Black Bears (Ursus Thibetanus Formosanus)|url=http://www.bioone.org.ezproxy.is.ed.ac.uk/doi/full/10.5735/086.048.0502|journal=Annales Zoologici Fennici|language=en|volume=48|issue=5|pages=275–286|doi=10.5735/086.048.0502}}</ref>
Black Bears are widely confirmed induced ovulators. It was observed that most females kept separate from males did not ovulate, where as females kept in areas with male bears did. Mating between the bears caused elevated progesterone levels and this was seen by increased progesterone levels measured in the bears in the months that followed the mating seasons.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Okano|first=Tsukasa|last2=Nakamura|first2=Sachiko|last3=Nakashita|first3=Rumiko|last4=Komatsu|first4=Takeshi|last5=Murase|first5=Tetsuma|last6=Asano|first6=Makoto|last7=Tsubota|first7=Toshio|date=2006|title=Incidence of Ovulation without Coital Stimuli in Captive Japanese Black Bears (Ursus thibetanus japonicus) based on Serum Progesterone Profiles|url=https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jvms/68/10/68_10_1133/_article/-char/ja/|journal=Journal of Veterinary Medical Science|volume=68|issue=10|pages=1133–1137|doi=10.1292/jvms.68.1133}}</ref> In black bears the presence of a males was enough to cause a notable rise in progesterone levels even without mating but mating. This could suggest that [[Pheromone|pheromonal]]/[[chemosensory]] factors could also contribute to induced ovulation in some species.<ref name=":02" />
Induced ovulation is able to occur in some fish species. In china freshwater fish including a variety of [[carp]] types, [[bream]] and loach are able to be induced to ovulate by using agonists of [[dopamine]]. This induction of ovulation from drugs is able to cause a predictable ovulation period and is very beneficial to farming of these species. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peter|first=Richard E.|last2=Lin|first2=Hao-Ren|last3=Van Der Kraak|first3=Glen|date=1988-11-01|title=Induced ovulation and spawning of cultured freshwater fish in China: Advances in application of GnRH analogues and dopamine antagonists|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0044848688900804|journal=Aquaculture|series=Induced Spawning of Asian Fishes|volume=74|issue=1|pages=1–10|doi=10.1016/0044-8486(88)90080-4}}</ref>
== In cattle == The natural cycle of spontaneous ovulation occurs in species such as [[Cattle|cows]]. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bogle|first=O. A.|last2=Ratto|first2=M. H.|last3=Adams|first3=G. P.|date=2011-08-01|title=Evidence for the conservation of biological activity of ovulation-inducing factor in seminal plasma|url=http://www.reproduction-online.org/content/142/2/277|journal=Reproduction|language=en|volume=142|issue=2|pages=277–283|doi=10.1530/REP-11-0042|issn=1470-1626|pmid=21652637}}</ref> There is a great demand for ovulation to be induced in cattle as it allows farmers to synchronize their cattle to ovulate at the same time, helping improve the efficiency of dairy farming. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wiltbank|first=Milo C.|last2=Pursley|first2=J. Richard|date=2014-01-01|title=The cow as an induced ovulator: Timed AI after synchronization of ovulation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0093691X13003828|journal=Theriogenology|volume=81|issue=1|pages=170–185|doi=10.1016/j.theriogenology.2013.09.017}}</ref> Induced ovulation can be utilized during the warmer seasons to increase plasma progesterone and improve the fertility of the cattle. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=De Rensis|first=F.|last2=Valentini|first2=R.|last3=Gorrieri|first3=F.|last4=Bottarelli|first4=E.|last5=Lopez-Gatius|first5=F.|date=2008-06-01|title=Inducing ovulation with hCG improves the fertility of dairy cows during the warm season|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0093691X08000642|journal=Theriogenology|volume=69|issue=9|pages=1077–1082|doi=10.1016/j.theriogenology.2008.01.020}}</ref> However, ovulation can only be induced in cows with mature follicles and merely initiates lutenization, it does not reduce the time for ovulation.
There are a number of methods that are used to induce ovulation in cattle such as: artificial insemination, introducing a number of hormones such as chorionic gonadotrophin, hCG and LH. As well as injecting progesterone by intravaginal devices called PRIDs (progesterone-releasing intravaginal devices) <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yavas|first=Y.|last2=Wallon|first2=J.S.|date=2000-07-01|title=Induction of ovulation in postpartum suckled beef cows: A review|url=http://www.theriojournal.com/article/S0093-691X(00)00322-8/pdf|journal=Theriogenology|language=English|volume=54|issue=1|doi=10.1016/S0093-691X(00)00322-8|issn=0093-691X}}</ref> ==In cats== Domestic [[cat]]s are often described as induced ovulators. During intromission, the penis probably causes distension of the posterior vagina and induces release of [[gonadotropin releasing hormone]] (GnRH) from the [[hypothalamus]] via neuroendocrine reflexes. A surge of [[Luteinizing hormone|luteinising hormone]] (LH) occurs within minutes of mating. With multiple matings, the LH surge is greater and lasts longer than when only one mating occurs. There are reports of ovulation without mating in cats. Spontaneous ovulation not only occurs in cats, but occurs with some frequency. It appears that non-copulatory ovulation may be possible in response to a variety of visual, auditory or olfactory cues. It is more appropriate to consider domestic cats to be both an induced and spontaneous ovulator.<ref>{{cite web|title=Estrus|url=http://vetbook.org/wiki/cat/index.php/Estrus|year=2012|publisher=The University of Sydney|accessdate=September 12, 2014}}</ref>
==In rabbits== It has been known since 1905<ref>{{cite journal|author=Heape, W.|year=1905|title=Ovulation and degeneration of ova in the rabbit.|journal=Proc. R. Soc. B|volume=76|pages=260–268|doi=10.1098/rspb.1905.0019}}</ref> that domestic [[rabbit]]s are physically induced ovulators, although they may also ovulate spontaneously. Early reports stated that simply having an oestrous doe in close proximity to a buck can induce ovulation, although there were no data presented in these early reports.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Staples, R.E.|journal=J. Reprod. Fert.|title=Behavioural induction of ovulation in the oestrous rabbit.|year=1967|volume=13|pages=429–435|doi=10.1530/jrf.0.0130429}}</ref>
==In camelids== [[Dromedary]] camels (''Camelus dromedarius''), [[bactrian camel]]s (''Camelus bactrianus''), [[llama]]s (''Lama glama'') and [[alpaca]]s (''Lama pacos'') are all induced ovulators.<ref name="Chen" /><ref>Bravo, P. W., J. A. Skidmore, and X. X. Zhao. "[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Walter_Bravo2/publication/12395230_Reproductive_aspects_and_storage_of_semen_in_camelidae_Anim_Reprod_Sci/links/5570459508aeab777228b986.pdf Reproductive aspects and storage of semen in Camelidae.]" Animal Reproduction Science 62.1 (2000): 173-193.</ref>
===Bactrian camel=== Bactrian camels ovulate after insemination of semen into the vagina; it is the seminal plasma, but not the spermatozoa, which induces ovulation. Ovulation occurs in 87% of females after insemination: 66% ovulate within 36 h and the rest by 48 h (the same as natural mating). The least amount of semen required to elicit ovulation is about 1.0 ml.<ref name="Chen">{{cite journal|journal=J. Reprod. Fert.|year=1985|volume=74|issue=2|pages=335–339|title=Semen-induced ovulation in the bactrian camel (Camelus bactrianus).|author=Chen, B.X., Yuen, Z.X. and Pan, G.W.|doi=10.1530/jrf.0.0740335}}<!--|accessdate=September 12, 2014--></ref>
===Alpaca=== In alpaca, follicles ovulate approximately 26 h after coital stimulation. Mounting accompanied by intromission is necessary to provide adequate stimulation for LH release and subsequent ovulation.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Fernandez-Baca, S., Madden, D.H.L. and Novoa, C.|year=1970|title=Effect of different mating stimuli on induction of ovulation in the alpaca.|journal=J. Reprod. Fert.|volume=22|pages=261–267|doi=10.1530/jrf.0.0220261}}</ref> Deposition of semen, which contains ovulation-inducing factor (OIF),<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Ovulation-inducing factor in seminal plasma: A review|last = Adams, G.P., Ratto, M.H.|first = |date = 2012|journal = Animal Reproduction Science|doi = 10.1016/j.anireprosci.2012.10.004|pmid =|volume=136|pages=148–156}}</ref> has been shown to increase the chance of pregnancy. Prolonged copulation, causing abrasion and inflammation of the uterus, may enhance absorption of OIF.
==References== {{reflist}} {{Ethology}}
[[Category:Ethology]] [[Category:Sexual reproduction]] [[Category:Reproduction in mammals]] [[Category:Reproduction in animals]] [[Category:Breeding]] [[Category:Camels]] [[Category:Cats]] [[Category:Rabbits and hares]] [[Category:Menstrual cycle]] [[Category:Reproduction]] [[Category:Hormones]] [[Category:Zoology]]

{{User sandbox}} <!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE --> This is my sandbox.
= Pseudopregnancy =
Pseudopregnancy is the term used to describe a false [[pregnancy]] in the wider mammalian species. It is a physical state whereby all the signs and symptoms<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balhara|first=YatanPal Singh|last2=Yadav|first2=Tarun|last3=Kataria|first3=DineshKumar|date=2012-01-01|title=Pseudocyesis Versus Delusion of Pregnancy: Differential Diagnoses to be Kept in Mind|url=http://www.ijpm.info/text.asp?2012/34/1/82/96167|journal=Indian Journal of Psychological Medicine|language=en|volume=34|issue=1|doi=10.4103/0253-7176.96167}}</ref> of pregnancy are exhibited, with the exception of the presence of a [[Fetus|foetus]]. In humans this state is called pseudocyesis, with this term being derived from the Greek pseudes (false) and kyesis (pregnancy)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balhara|first=YatanPal Singh|last2=Yadav|first2=Tarun|last3=Kataria|first3=DineshKumar|date=2012-01-01|title=Pseudocyesis Versus Delusion of Pregnancy: Differential Diagnoses to be Kept in Mind|url=http://www.ijpm.info/text.asp?2012/34/1/82/96167|journal=Indian Journal of Psychological Medicine|language=en|volume=34|issue=1|doi=10.4103/0253-7176.96167}}</ref> . Symptoms of pseudopregnancy can range from abdominal enlargement to experiencing the sensation of foetal movement<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barglow|first=P.|date=December 1964|title=PSEUDOCYESIS AND PSYCHIATRIC SEQUELAE OF STERILIZATION|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14209739|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=11|pages=571–580|issn=0003-990X|pmid=14209739}}</ref>. Whilst a simulated pregnancy occurs when a woman, knowing she is not pregnant, claims to be so and the presence of a tumour can alter the endocrine environment, resulting in physical changes similar to those observed in pregnancy, pseudopregnancy is distinct from these other forms of false pregnancy<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hardwick|first=P. J.|last2=Fitzpatrick|first2=C.|date=1981-12-01|title=Fear, folie and phantom pregnancy: pseudocyesis in a fifteen-year-old girl.|url=http://bjp.rcpsych.org/content/139/6/558|journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry|language=en|volume=139|issue=6|pages=558–560|doi=10.1192/bjp.139.6.558|issn=0007-1250|pmid=7332863}}</ref>. == Pseudopregnancy in Cats == [[File:BEN Bengalian kitten (4492540155).jpg|alt=Kitten|thumb|[[Kitten|'''Kitten''']]]] Domestic cats are a species that can become pseudopregnant. This occurs when a female cat ovulates but is not fertilised due to breeding with an infertile male, spontaneous ovulation or due to the owner stimulating ovulation. In pseudo pregnancy in cats the corpus luteum is present after ovulation and persists for around 37 days. The length of pseudopregnancy varies in cats greatly with the mean duration being 41 days. After pseudopregnancy, the female cat returns to proestrus and can become pregnant again. The pseudo-pregnancy lasts around half the length of a normal pregnancy in cats which does not occur in all other species such as dogs. This is advantageous to the cats as they can conceive earlier making them more efficient in reproduction<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Petersen|first1=Amanda|date=2015|title=Reproductive physiology of the female cat|url=http://stud.epsilon.slu.se/7921/|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>.
In cats, the progesterone and estradiol profiles in pseudo-pregnancy are very different when compared to normal pregnancy. During Pseudopregnancy estradiol increased straight after mating and then decreased returning to normal levels. The amount of progesterone did not increase until 2-3 days post copulation, then the level rises until day 21 post copulation where after it gradually declined returning to normal levels<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Petersen|first1=Amanda|title=Reproductive physiology of the female cat|date=2015|url=http://stud.epsilon.slu.se/7921/}}</ref>. [[File:Parson Russell Terrier Puppy 3 Months Old.jpg|alt=Puppy|thumb|'''[[Puppy]]''']] == Pseudopregnancy in Dogs ==
Pseudo-pregnancy is a normal physiologic process that occurs in female dogs. It is seen 45-60 days after a normal estrous (heat) period. After ovulation, progesterone levels rise. Pseudo-pregnancy happens when the progesterone levels begin to fall as decreasing progesterone leads to an increase of the hormone prolactin. Prolactin is responsible for the behaviours seen during pseudo-pregnancy. Dogs may exhibit mothering of toys, nesting or aggression. Mammary development and milk production are common. Pseudopregnancy can also be acutely induced by spaying (removing of ovaries) a dog near the end of estrus. Spaying removes the source of progesterone and induces a rise in prolactin.
Permanent prevention of pseudopregnancy is accomplished with spaying<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vmth/local_resources/pdfs/repro_pdfs/cepseudopregnancy.pdf|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== Pseudopregnancy in Swine == [[File:Sow and five piglets.jpg|alt=Pig with piglets|thumb|'''[[Pig]] with [[Piglet (animal)|piglets]]''']] Pseudopregnancy or "Not-in-Pig" is a condition that occurs when female exhibit physiological and behavioral signs associated with pregnancy, but there are no fetuses present. Pseudopregnancy can occur when all of the embryos are resorbed after the maternal recognition of pregnancy (days 10-15 postmating) and before fetal calcification (days 35-40 of gestation). The sow remains anestrus for prolonged periods, often as long as 115 days. These animals may exhibit varying degrees of udder development, but fail to deliver any pigs. The timely identification and removal of non-pregnant females from the breeding herd is important because it reduces both non-productive sow days and production costs <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://projects.ncsu.edu/project/swine_extension/swinereports/2001/02physflow.htm|title=Real-time Ultrasonography and diagnosis of pseudopregnancy in swine|website=projects.ncsu.edu|access-date=2017-09-27}}</ref>.
Techniques used for pregnancy diagnosis in swine include ultrasonography, amplitude depth machines, and Doppler machines<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://old.pork.org/filelibrary/factsheets/pigfactsheets/newfactsheets/08-04-03g.pdf|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== Neuroendocrine Pathway of Pseudopregnancy in Rats == The initiation of pseudopregnancy is basically similar to the pregnancy regarding the activation of progestational state. The neuroendocrine pathway of pseudopregnancy in rats is mainly initiated by the nocturnal surge of prolactin<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Terkel|first=J.|date=1988|title=Neuroendocrine processes in the establishment of pregnancy and pseudopregnancy in rats|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3287417|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|volume=13|issue=1-2|pages=5–28|issn=0306-4530|pmid=3287417}}</ref>. The hormone prolactin produced regulates the activation and early maintenance of corpus luteum. The corpus luteum is known as a site of progesterone production in order for the uterus undergoes a decidual process. There are two types of induced pseudopregnancy; coitally induced pseudopregnancy and non-coitally induced pseudopregnancy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Terkel|first=J.|date=1986|title=Neuroendocrinology of coitally and noncoitally induced pseudopregnancy|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3555247|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=474|pages=76–94|issn=0077-8923|pmid=3555247}}</ref> [[File:London Scruffy Rat.jpg|alt=Rat|thumb|'''[[Rat]]''']] The coitally induced pseudopregnancy is stimulated by the action of copulation. The copulation stimulation causes the nocturnal prolactin elevation which then activates the corpus luteum. The multiple intromission coital pattern initiates the neuroendocrine reflex which results in the sufficient progesterone secretion in pseudopregnancy. However, induction of pseudopregnancy requires adrenergic system to be activated and simultaneously inhibits the cholinergic system<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Terkel|first=J.|date=1986|title=Neuroendocrinology of coitally and noncoitally induced pseudopregnancy|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3555247|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=474|pages=76–94|issn=0077-8923|pmid=3555247}}</ref>.
The non-coitally induced pseudopregnancy requires the presence of the initial stimulus until the levels of progesterone are sufficiently elevated to produce positive feedback on secretion of prolactin. The initial stimulus can be in a form of some socio-environmental factors, such as concaveation with foster pups in virgin rats or cohabitation in all-female groups in mice<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Terkel|first=J.|date=1986|title=Neuroendocrinology of coitally and noncoitally induced pseudopregnancy|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3555247|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=474|pages=76–94|issn=0077-8923|pmid=3555247}}</ref>. == References == <references /> [[Category:Reproduction in animals]] [[Category:Reproduction in mammals]] [[Category:Uterus]] [[Category:Fertility]] [[Category:Human pregnancy]] [[Category:Cats]] [[Category:Pigs]] [[Category:Dogs]] [[Category:Rats]] [[Category:Reproductive health]]
